awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Controlling Pressure-Induced Transformation in Rare Earth Orthophosphates
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Sudden through to slowly growing cracks in high temperature ceramic components such as combustors, nozzles, and thermal insulation in aircraft engines, turbines, and rockets can lead to catastrophic failure. Some unique ceramics undergo a change in their shape and volume to a new crystal structure when they are deformed, which can be harnessed to impart increased toughness in a material by absorbing energy caused by an impact or propagating crack. This project is determining how to use chemistry to control the point at which the change to a new crystal structure occurs and its speed of transformation. The information and new materials discovered in this research can be useful in designing fiber coatings for ceramic matrix composites with better performance (superior mechanical properties) for high temperature aerospace applications. Both undergraduate and graduate students in Materials Science and Engineering are being trained and mentored. This project is developing science learning modules for use by local elementary school teachers from school districts with a high percentage of minority students and the Rocky Mountain Camp for the Dyslexic. These complementary education and outreach components broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering in an effort to meet the U.S. need for expanding the science and technology workforce with more highly qualified people. This project will help strengthen U.S. innovation and economic competitiveness in the area of turbine engines and in terms of education.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project is establishing the influence of chemistry, grain size, temperature, and stress state on pressure-induced phase transformation kinetics in rare earth (RE) orthophosphate ceramics (REPO4 crystal structure).  Phase transformations in these materials are being examined using a range of techniques that include high-temperature nanoindentation, transmission electron microscopy, and diamond anvil cell (combined with Raman spectroscopy). One goal is to enable precise control over the trigger for the plasticity transformation in coatings for improved ceramic matrix composites. The influence of kinetic effects on the transformation onset pressure and degree of reversibility are being identified.  Insights gained through this research are aiding in the science-based design of ceramic composites, components, and devices in which pressure-induced transformation must be triggered with precise timing for maximal effect. This work addresses a grand challenge of the field to understand the factors controlling phase transformation kinetics that can lead directly to new ways to process metastable materials with enhanced functionality.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
This award addressed societally important issues in materials and advanced manufacturing related to increasing turbine efficiency and performance in high-temperature aerospace applications, using fundamental science to help strengthen U.S. innovation and economic competitiveness in the aerospace industry. We investigated the deformation behavior of ceramics used to enhance ceramic matrix composite (CMC) toughness and to impart resistance to catastrophic CMC failure. Our study focused on rare earth orthophosphate ceramics, which resist high temperatures and corrosive environments. We synthesized several rare earth orthophosphate compositions for the first time. We discovered the type of stress applied to these materials matters more in determining the material's deformation behavior than the material's chemistry. Complex stress states with a high degree of shear were found to catalyze two distinct types of energy-absorbing structural changes, which can potentially contribute to enhanced material performance. By explaining how complex stress states yield desirable mechanical behavior in materials, we move ideas from the earliest stages of basic science through technology development, working towards increasing energy efficiency in aerospace applications and improving the reliability and durability of functional coatings.

This award facilitated over half a decade of outreach efforts with the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Children. Dyslexia is a learning disability that affects reading and language-processing skills, and children with dyslexia often have concomitant disabilities including ADHD and executive function disorder. Approximately 30-40 campers per year benefited from camp activities exposing them to science and engineering concepts through creative, hands-on modules designed and delivered by Colorado School of Mines faculty and graduate students, enriching campers' educational interventions. Over a dozen faculty members were trained and participated in the camp, institutionalizing Colorado School of Mines' collaboration with the camp. Continuation of these efforts immediately after the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic helped remediate learning deficits for already underserved students. These efforts foster inclusion by encouraging full participation of children with disabilities in STEM fields.

To date, the project has produced four peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development. In addition, a U.S. patent was granted for technology based on scientific discoveries identified in this project. An extensive suite of teaching modules regarding ceramic science concepts are publicly and freely available on the Mines Repository website, including four teaching modules and one teacher-training module, which were developed for use at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Children but are suitable for instruction in any K-8 classroom. This project trained four graduate students, three undergraduate students, and three post-doctoral trainees in independent scientific inquiry. Graduates of this project have filled competitive positions in U.S. aerospace, semiconductor, and glass industries.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2022
Modified by: Corinne E Packard

Images (1 of )
  • High-pressure experiments determined that a structural transformation in dysprosium orthophosphate is sensitive to the stress state, with less uniform pressures promoting earlier transformation.
    Jai Sharma
    Copyrighted
    Corinne E Packard
    Transformation pressure for dysprosium orthophosphate is sensitive to shear stress
  • Photograph of two graduate students (Jai Sharma and Henry Afful) standing in an x-ray hutch after completing high-pressure experiments
    Corinne Packard
    Copyrighted
    Corinne E Packard
    Photograph of two graduate students standing in an x-ray hutch after completing high-pressure experiments
  • Photo montage of graduate students and elementary school students participating in science modules based on ceramic materials at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Kids.
    Jai Sharma
    Copyrighted
    Corinne E Packard
    5 photo montage of graduate students and elementary school students at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Kids
  • Raman spectroscopy data for newly synthesized rare earth orthophosphate composition, Gd0.5Dy0.5PO4, as a function of pressure, showing emergence of new peaks at 10.1 GPa due to transformation to a different, high-pressure crystal structure.
    Corinne Packard
    Copyrighted
    Corinne E Packard
    Raman spectroscopy data for Gd0.5Dy0.5PO4 as a function of pressure, showing emergence of a new phase at 10.1 GPa
  • Two girls with identical Lego (TM) block sets showing different structural arrangements to illustrate concepts from a 'Polymorphism in Ceramics' science module at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Children. The module was developed by students and a faculty member at the Colorado School of Mines.
    Corinne Packard
    Copyrighted
    Corinne E Packard
    Two girls with identical Lego (TM) block sets showing different structural arrangements at a camp in the Rocky Mountains
